name: Pidgeot

attacks.name: Hurricane
attacks.text: Unless this attack Knocks Out the Defending Pokémon, return the Defending Pokémon and all cards attached to it to your opponent's hand.

flavorText: When hunting, it skims the surface of water at high speed to pick off unwary prey such as Magikarp.

strengths: Hurricane bounces opponent's Pokemon and all attached cards to hand
Free retreat cost provides excellent mobility
Hurricane disrupts opponent's energy and evolution progress
weaknesses: 80 HP is low for a Stage 2
Hurricane doesn't work if it knocks out the target
Stage 2 evolution is slow to set up
Lightning weakness is problematic against Electabuzz
synergies: Double Colorless Energy - powers up attacks faster
Gust of Wind - choose what to Hurricane back
counters: Low HP Pokemon - Hurricane won't work if it KOs
Decks with quick setup - can recover from Hurricane

competitiveHistory: Pidgeot from Jungle had an interesting niche with its Hurricane attack, which could reset an opponent's evolved Pokemon and all their attached energy. However, the Stage 2 evolution requirement, 4 energy cost, and the limitation that it doesn't work on KOs limited its competitive viability. The free retreat was appreciated but not enough to make it a tournament staple. It saw occasional play in control-oriented decks but was not a meta-defining card.

rulings.ruling: Hurricane returns the Defending Pokemon and ALL cards attached to it (Energy, Trainer cards like Defender, etc.) to the opponent's hand.
If Hurricane knocks out the Defending Pokemon, the Pokemon and attached cards are discarded as normal, not returned to hand.
Hurricane's effect happens even if the opponent's Pokemon has 0 HP from the damage, as long as it's not technically 'Knocked Out' by that damage.
